text: Patient: Uh, and then look at the other options. So, is that, is the one that is phase one is that, that window like a real tight window. That seven days from now, it’s gonna be closed? Doctor: Umm. I don’t know that. So, when I spoke to Dr. P_, all she let me know was that there was a slot. You know, that would be something that we would say once you’ve decided or that we’ve given you the consent form that we have a potential patient who’s interested, that they would save that slot for you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they would, I assume, that there is going to need to be a twenty-eight day washout of your current therapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then, maybe that you have to repeat scans prior to that. Um, the adrenal glands. The, the big wild card there right now what I can clearly state that it is not specific. I don’t know what it is. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And again, that’s the radiologists can’t agree on what it is. Patient: So, would I have to have something done to go into the adrenal glands or, uh, the, the tests that confirm that whether it is cancer or not cancer? Doctor: Um, no. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. And then if you decided to go with chemotherapy, it would be just one of the many spots that we would watch for change in response to.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: It’s on the uh - it’s called the left iliac lymph node. So the left iliac lymph node is basically um where the blood vessel called the aorta splits up into the two iliac arteries. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then there are lymph nodes on each side. So I would say if I, if I could go through your abdomen like three inches, I’d hit it; it’s on the left side. Patient: Now I did have uh a gist and I had that surgery July the thirteenth. I remember that was in the stomach. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: So is it in somewhere in comparison…? Well I guess they’re two independent things then. Doctor: It’s two, it’s two independent things. You are a extremely low risk gist tumor. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And and the risk is not determined by the size. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s determined by um how rapidly the cells are dividing, so there’s something that’s called a mitosis. Patient: Uh hum.

text: Family Member: Mm Hmm. Doctor: It’s a treatment that only goes to the bones in prostate cancer and helps kill the cancer in the bones. Most of your disease was in the bones. Doctor: So at least on the up front CAT scan, not the latest one. Family Member: Oh, oh, oh Doctor: But I think the way back when CAT scan you had some. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay but they were very small and they may not be something at all significant. So you know I think your last CAT scan again barely showed anything Patient: Right. Doctor: so I don’t think we need to worry about those. But doing that Xofigo treatment would absolutely be another valid option if you don’t want to do chemotherapy. So the good news is that you have some options for standard treatment and you have some options for clinical trials. So you know either way we have options. I’m just reluctant to switch things if the scans don’t show us any change. Family Member 2: Right, right.

text: Patient: Yes. Doctor: It sounds like we’re going to keep you on the study for now. In order to do so, we have to stop the medication to allow this anemia to recover. Hopefully, it will. Family Member: She’ll be here tomorrow. Doctor: She actually had to leave unexpectedly because her house had some flooding which she had to take care of, which is why she’s not here. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, uh, we will schedule the, uh, complete blood count which includes hemoglobin for next Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday, the early part of next week. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And we will have all that completed before September fifth. text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So you’d come in in the morning and you’d get your CT scan and you’d have your bone scan. And two or three hours after the two scans are done you would see me and by that time you would have the results. Have the images on my computer to look at them and discuss the results with you. The other possibility is to do the scans at a local radiology facility and then to get the images with the CDs and have the reports, get them sent to me and have one brought to you physically. But you know like I said if you agree with me, is to do it here. Patient: Yes. Doctor: If it’s not too much of a hardship. Patient: Very good. If when and needed. Doctor: Yes. And again that might not be for another six to twelve months. It could be sooner, a bit later depending on how or if your PSA increases. Patient: Oh. Doctor: Now one of the things that I also wanted to discuss with you was some um of the clinical trials that we’re doing. In other words, research studies – Patient: Uh huh. DOC - investigating new approaches which might not be approved for prostate cancer. Doctor: For prostate cancer. And one of the um trials that we’re doing, which we are quite excited about is this concept of using high doses of testosterone as a therapy for prostate cancer. Patient: As a therapy? Now testosterone feeds the cancer, correct? Doctor: Correct. I knew you’d say that. Patient: Uh huh.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
